items.abstract: <jats:p>If<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="$V$"><mml:mi>V</mml:mi></mml:math>is a Lyapunov function of an equation<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="${{du} \mathord{\left/  {\vphantom {{du} {dt}}} \right.  \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {dt}} = u' = Zu$"><mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi>d</mml:mi><mml:mi>u</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mo>/</mml:mo><mml:mrow><mml:mi>d</mml:mi><mml:mi>t</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mrow><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:msup><mml:mi>u</mml:mi><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msup><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi><mml:mi>u</mml:mi></mml:math>in a Banach space then asymptotic stability of an equilibrium point may be easily proved if it is known that<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="$\sup \left( {V'} \right) < 0$"><mml:mo>sup</mml:mo><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:msup><mml:mi>V</mml:mi><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msup><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo><</mml:mo><mml:mn>0</mml:mn></mml:math>on sufficiently small spheres centered at the equilibrium point. In this paper weak asymptotic stability is proved for a bounded infinitesimal generator<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="$Z$"><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi></mml:math>under a weaker assumption<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="$V' \leqslant 0$"><mml:msup><mml:mi>V</mml:mi><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msup><mml:mo>≤</mml:mo><mml:mn>0</mml:mn></mml:math>(which alone implies ordinary stability only) if some observability condition, involving<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="$Z$"><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi></mml:math>and the Frechet derivative of<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="${V'}$"><mml:msup><mml:mi>V</mml:mi><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msup></mml:math>, is satisfied. The proof is based on an extension of LaSalle's invariance principle, which yields convergence in a weak topology and uses a strongly continuous Lyapunov function. The theory is illustrated with an example of an integro-differential equation of interest in the theory of chemical processes. In this case strong asymptotic stability is deduced from the weak one and explicit sufficient conditions for stability are given. In the case of a normal infinitesimal generator<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="$Z$"><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi></mml:math>in a Hilbert space, strong asymptotic stability is proved under the following assumptions<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="$Z* + Z$"><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi><mml:mo>*</mml:mo><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi></mml:math>is weakly negative definite and<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="${\mathrm{Ker }}Z = \left\{ 0 \right\}$"><mml:mtext>Ker </mml:mtext><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mrow><mml:mo>{</mml:mo><mml:mn>0</mml:mn><mml:mo>}</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:math>. The proof is based on spectral theory.</jats:p>
title: A weak invariance principle and asymptotic stability for evolution equations with bounded generators

title: Sizes of particles formed during municipal wastewater treatment
subject: Environmental Engineering
Water Science and Technology

items.abstract: <jats:p>Municipal wastewater sludge was produced by chemical coagulation of synthetic wastewater (sww) based on Synthene Scarlet P3GL disperse dye and real municipal wastewater (nww), coagulated by commercial coagulants PAX (prepolymerised aluminum coagulant) and PIX (a ferric coagulant based on Fe2(SO4)3). An attempt was made to correlate the sludge’s dewatering capacity (in terms of capillary suction time—CST) with operation parameters for wastewater treatment, size distribution and specific surface area of the sludge particles. It was found that the presence of phosphate ions in the system facilitates the removal efficiency of the above-mentioned dye (L) due to the interaction between the dye molecules and H2PO4− ions. Unlike sww, negatively charged organic substances (sorg) in nww are directly adsorbed on the surface of colloidal particles {Fe(OH)3} and {Al(OH)3} (prtc). It was also discovered that an increase in the dose of a coagulant led to an increase of CST for sww sludge and to a decrease of CST for nww sludge. It has been suggested that flocs composed of spherical {Al(OH)3} units possessed more internal space for water than aggregates consisting of rod-shaped {Fe(OH)3} units and, consequently, it is more difficult to remove water from Al-sww sludge than from Fe-sww. The results obtained showed that smaller particles dominate in sww sludge, while larger particles are prevalent in nww sludge. To explain this distinct difference in the size distribution of particles in sludge obtained with the use of Al3+ and Fe3+, simple models of aggregation and agglomeration-flocculation processes (aaf) of treated wastewater have been proposed. Except for PIX in nww, the analyzed particles of the investigated types of sludge were characterized by similar specific surface area (Sps), regardless of the kind of sludge or the applied coagulant. Slightly larger, negatively-charged sorg bridges, anchored directly on the surface of positive prtc are more effective in closing the structure of nww sludge than small L bridges of the dye molecules anchored on the surface of prtc via H2PO4−. All the discovered aspects could lead to improved performance of wastewater treatment plants (WWTP) by increasing the efficiency of sludge dewatering.</jats:p>
title: Study of Sludge Particles Formed during Coagulation of Synthetic and Municipal Wastewater for Increasing the Sludge Dewatering Efficiency
